{{unsourced|date=October 2008}} '''Popular Socialism''' ('''[[Danish language|Danish]]''': ''Folkesocialisme'') is a distinct [[Scandinavia]]n [[socialist]] current. Around the world there are many parties called [[Popular Socialist Party (disambiguation)|Popular Socialist Party]] or likewise, which does not really imply any specific ideological direction. For example, the [[Popular Socialist Party (Mexico)|Popular Socialist Party]] of [[Mexico]] is a rather hardline [[communist party]], whereas the [[Spain|Spanish]] [[Popular Socialist Party (Spain)|PSP]] was a left-[[Social democracy|social democrat]] formation. But in the Scandinavian context the term can be said to represent a distinct ideological tendency, originating from [[Aksel Larsen]]'s split from the [[Communist Party of Denmark]] in 1956. Larsen founded [[Socialistisk Folkeparti]] (Socialist People's Party) which placed itself between [[communism]] and [[social democracy]]. In [[Norway]] a similar party, [[Socialist People's Party (Norway)|SF]], was formed through an anti-[[NATO]]/anti-[[European Economic Community]]-split from the [[Det Norske Arbeiderparti|social democrats]]. SF later became the back-bone of [[Sosialistisk Venstreparti]] (Socialist Left Party). Today, both the Danish SF and the Norwegian SV identify their ideological base as 'Popular Socialism'. In [[Sweden]] the term has sometimes been used in the Left, and there were at one point discussions within the rightist section of the [[VÃ¤nsterpartiet|Communist Party]] on forming a political project with the Danish SF as model. But that split was avoided, although the Nordic contacts and [[Eurocommunism]] became important influences in the Swedish party.
